paper_metadata.title: Exchangeable potassium reserve in a Brazilian savanna Oxisol after nine years under different cotton production systems
paper_metadata.research_focus: Evaluation of K dynamics and exchangeable reserves in soil profile and partial K balance under different cotton production systems in a clayey Oxisol in the Brazilian Cerrado.
paper_metadata.soil_k_relevance: The study's primary focus is on soil potassium, specifically its dynamics, exchangeable reserves, and partial balance under various long-term agricultural management systems.

research_context.study_objectives: To evaluate the influence of soil management and crop succession or rotation combinations with cotton on K dynamics and exchangeable reserves in the soil profile, and the partial balance of K after nine years of cultivation in a clayey Oxisol in the Cerrado.
research_context.soil_k_research_role: Soil K is the central element of the research, with the study designed to understand its behavior (dynamics, reserves, balance) under different agricultural practices.
research_context.geographic_setting: Santa Helena de Goiás, Goiás, Brazil (17°50’37” S, 50°35’52” W, and altitude 557 m). Located in the Brazilian Savanna (Cerrado biome).
research_context.environmental_conditions: Climate classified as Aw according to the Köppen-Geiger system, with an average rainfall of 1,800 mm, concentrated from October to March.
research_context.agricultural_context: Long-term experiment (nine years) involving cotton cultivation in different production systems, including monoculture, annual succession with soybean, and rotation with soybean/maize, with and without Urochloa ruziziensis (ruzigrass) as a cover crop. Prior to the experiment, the area was cultivated with cotton for three years, and before that, soybean monoculture, with the soil prepared annually by plowing and harrowing.
research_context.study_design: Randomized block design with four replications. Four cotton production systems treatments were compared. A site with native Cerrado vegetation adjacent to the experiment was used as a reference for exchangeable K and OM content in the soil profile.
research_context.temporal_scope: The experiment was conducted for nine years, from August 2005 to October 2014. Soil samples were collected in October 2014 for final analysis, with initial soil analysis performed in August 2005.
research_context.spatial_scope: The experimental plot for each cropping system covered an area of 576 m² (14.4 × 40 m). Soil was sampled in layers up to 100 cm depth (0-5, 6-10, 11-20, 21-30, 31-60, and 61-100 cm).

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Initial soil condition, calculated assuming soil bulk density of 1.0 kg dm⁻³
After nine years of cultivation, calculated from 0.53 cmol c dm⁻³ in 0-20 cm layer, assuming soil bulk density of 1.0 kg dm⁻³

treatment_effects.NTS: 0.53 cmol c dm⁻³ (829 kg ha⁻¹ KCl)
treatment_effects.CSTCSM: 0.26 cmol c dm⁻³ (407 kg ha⁻¹ KCl)
treatment_effects.NTS vs CSTCSM: NTS retained ~422 kg ha⁻¹ of additional KCl in 0-20 cm

pool_characterizations.measurement_conditions: Native Cerrado soil condition (0-20 cm layer), calculated from 0.38 cmol c dm⁻³, assuming soil bulk density of 1.0 kg dm⁻³
pool_characterizations.temporal_variation: Reflects a stabilized state mainly due to biological recycling

pool_characterizations.analytical_method: Mehlich-1 extraction, flame photometer, calculated assuming soil bulk density of 1.0 kg dm⁻³

treatment_effects.CSTCM: Almost half of K detected was in the layer below 30 cm depth
treatment_effects.NTS: Almost 70 % remained in the topsoil layer (up to 30 cm)
treatment_effects.NTS (0-20 cm): Estimated stock corresponded to 63% of the 452 kg ha⁻¹ K₂O surplus
treatment_effects.CST treatments (0-20 cm): Maximum percentage retained was 34% of the surplus

assumptions: K export determined by multiplying crop yields by mean removal rates (17 kg K₂O/ton seed cotton, 20 kg K₂O/ton soybean, 3.7 kg K₂O/ton maize grains)

temporal_patterns.monitoring_frequency: Initial soil sampling in August 2005; final soil sampling in October 2014. No intermediate monitoring frequency reported for soil K.

long_term_trends.parameter: Exchangeable K distribution in soil profile
long_term_trends.trend_description: CST with cotton monoculture (CSTCM) favored K mobilization and leaching to deeper layers (below 30 cm) over the nine years. No-tillage system (NTS) with ruzigrass maintained K more concentrated in the topsoil (up to 30 cm).
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: Significant differences between treatments in K distribution, but not statistically compared between sampling depths.

long_term_trends.parameter: Soil K availability in 0-20 cm layer
long_term_trends.trend_description: Increased to values above the critical level (0.13 cmol c dm⁻³) in all production systems after nine years of fertilization.
long_term_trends.statistical_significance: Implied by the reported values being above critical level.

within_site_variability.variability_description: Highest absolute values detected in the upper layers (0-5 cm), decreasing progressively with depth, irrespective of the treatment.

between_site_differences.site_comparison: Comparison between four cotton production systems (CSTCM, CSTCSC, CSTCSM, NTS) and native Cerrado.

difference_magnitude.CSTCM_deeper_vs_NTS_deeper: CSTCM presented more than twice the K content in deeper layers (below 30 cm) compared to NTS
difference_magnitude.NTS_vs_CSTCSM_0-5cm: 93% higher in NTS (1.18 vs 0.61 cmol c dm⁻³)
difference_magnitude.NTS_vs_CSTCSM_6-10cm: 115% higher in NTS (0.69 vs 0.32 cmol c dm⁻³)
difference_magnitude.NTS_vs_CSTCSM_11-20cm: 117% higher in NTS (0.48 vs 0.22 cmol c dm⁻³)

scaling_considerations.scale_transition: From point measurements (composite samples from 10 points per depth) to plot-level (576 m²) and implications for broader agricultural systems.
scaling_considerations.scaling_approach: Weighted average for 0-20 cm layer to represent K availability for root activity.
scaling_considerations.uncertainty: Assumption of soil bulk density (1.0 kg dm⁻³) for K₂O equivalent calculations.

cycling_processes.description: Crop rotation including ruzigrass in NTS allowed better control of K dynamics, ensuring its circulation in the soil-plant compartments and reducing leaching.
cycling_processes.measurement_approach: Inferred from exchangeable K distribution and balance calculations.

cycling_processes.description: K contained in plant residues is quickly released into the soil solution with the death of plant tissue and presence of enough moisture, contributing to nutrition of the subsequent crop.

plant_soil_interactions.description: Urochloa species develop a root system that penetrates deeper into the soil, with a large volume of roots, enabling high K absorption, including non-exchangeable forms. K is transported mainly by diffusion from soil to root surface.
plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Continuous absorption by living plants throughout the year in NTS.
influencing_factors: Root system architecture (e.g., deep roots of ruzigrass)
Root hairs (increase surface area and concentration gradient)

plant_soil_interactions.interaction_type: K retention by soil organic matter (SOM) and CEC
plant_soil_interactions.description: Increased OM in NTS enlarges the storage capacity of K in the topsoil. SOM accounts for most CEC in highly weathered Oxisols, enhancing K retention and, therefore, for the retention of K in the soil profile.
plant_soil_interactions.temporal_patterns: Accumulation of SOM over nine years in NTS.
influencing_factors: Straw production and root development of cover crops

chemical_processes.characterization: K surplus from fertilization is susceptible to leaching losses, especially in conventional tillage systems and when K fertilization exceeds soil buffering capacity. Oxisols are typically well drained, increasing the importance of leaching as a potential K loss pathway.
chemical_processes.implications: Increased K loss from the system due to leaching out of the root exploration zone, especially in CSTCM where almost half of K was below 30 cm.

chemical_processes.characterization: K adsorbs in exchangeable positions on colloids. There is a weak K retention strength in highly weathered soils like Cerrado Oxisols due to low frequency of 2:1 clay minerals and competition with Ca and Mg from liming.
chemical_processes.implications: Influences the soil's capacity to retain K and its susceptibility to leaching.

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Conventional soil tillage (CST) with cotton monoculture (CSTCM)

soil_k_effects.exchangeable_k_distribution: Favored K mobilization to deeper layers (below 30 cm), with almost half of detected K in these layers.
soil_k_effects.k_leaching: Increased likelihood of K loss from the system due to leaching out of the root exploration zone.
soil_k_effects.k_balance: Highest cumulative K₂O surplus (617 kg ha⁻¹) and lowest offtake rate (47%).
soil_k_effects.k_storage_capacity: Limited SOM accumulation, favoring a disruption in K storage capacity in the topsoil.

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Conventional soil tillage (CST) with annual cotton-soybean-cotton succession (CSTCSC)

soil_k_effects.k_balance: Cumulative K₂O surplus of 247 kg ha⁻¹ and highest offtake rate (70%).
soil_k_effects.exchangeable_k_distribution: K levels statistically similar to CSTCSM and NTS at depths 21-30, 31-60, and 61-100 cm.

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: Conventional soil tillage (CST) with cotton/soybean/maize rotation (CSTCSM)

soil_k_effects.exchangeable_k_content_0-20cm: 0.26 cmol c dm⁻³ (407 kg ha⁻¹ KCl equivalent).
soil_k_effects.k_balance: Cumulative K₂O surplus of 485 kg ha⁻¹ and offtake rate of 48%.
soil_k_effects.exchangeable_k_distribution: K levels statistically similar to CSTCSC and NTS at depths 21-30, 31-60, and 61-100 cm.

experimental_treatments.treatment_description: No-tillage system (NTS) with cotton/soybean/maize rotation and Urochloa ruziziensis (ruzigrass) as a cover crop in the off-season

soil_k_effects.exchangeable_k_content_0-5cm: Highest K content (1.18 cmol c dm⁻³), 79% higher than mean of CST treatments.
soil_k_effects.exchangeable_k_content_0-20cm: 0.53 cmol c dm⁻³ (829 kg ha⁻¹ KCl equivalent), more than twice the K available for absorption compared to CSTCSM.
soil_k_effects.k_retention_topsoil: Almost 70% of exchangeable K remained in the topsoil layer (up to 30 cm).
soil_k_effects.k_dynamics_control: Allowed better control of K dynamics, ensuring its circulation in soil-plant compartments and reducing leaching.
soil_k_effects.k_storage_capacity: Increased organic matter (OM) enlarged K storage capacity in the topsoil.
soil_k_effects.k_balance: Cumulative K₂O surplus of 452 kg ha⁻¹ and offtake rate of 52%.
soil_k_effects.k_use_efficiency: Improved K use efficiency of fertilizers.

mechanisms: Straw production and abundant root development of U. ruziziensis
Cotton, maize, and soybean crop residues
Deep K recovery by ruzigrass root system

soil_k_impacts.k_input: Total cumulative K₂O applied: 1,170 kg ha⁻¹ (CSTCM), 834 kg ha⁻¹ (CSTCSC), 939 kg ha⁻¹ (CSTCSM, NTS).
soil_k_impacts.k_balance: Generated a surplus in nutrient balance in all systems, increasing soil K availability above critical levels.
soil_k_impacts.k_leaching: When K fertilization generates a positive balance exceeding soil buffering capacity, higher exchangeable K levels increase leaching.

management_practices.implementation_details: Mean annual fertilizations (kg ha⁻¹ K₂O): 130 for cotton, 46 for soybean, 137 for maize. All soybean fertilization was applied in the sowing furrow. Maize and cotton received all phosphate fertilizer and approximately 20 % of N and 50 % of K₂O in the sowing furrow. The remaining N and K₂O amounts were divided into two topdressing applications.
management_practices.spatial_effects: Influenced K distribution in soil profile.

soil_k_impacts.k_retention_potential: May promote an increase in CEC in soils with predominance of variable charges, enhancing potential for K retention by negative colloidal charges.

management_practices.implementation_details: 2,200 kg ha⁻¹ calcitic limestone (90% CaCO₃ equivalent) in Sept 2005. 2,000 kg ha⁻¹ dolomitic limestone (85% CaCO₃ equivalent) in Aug 2009. 1,000 kg ha⁻¹ phosphogypsum (PG) in Oct 2009. In CST treatments, these additives were incorporated up to 20 cm with plowing and harrowing and were broadcasted on the soil surface without incorporation in the NTS treatment.
management_practices.temporal_effects: Long-term effects on soil properties and K retention.
management_practices.spatial_effects: Incorporation depth varied by tillage system.

comparative_analysis.comparison_type: Tillage system and cropping pattern comparison
treatments_compared: NTS (No-Tillage System with Cotton/Soybean/Maize Rotation and Ruzigrass)

soil_k_differences.NTS_vs_CSTCM_K_distribution: NTS retained K in topsoil (70% in 0-30 cm), while CSTCM showed K mobilization to deeper layers (almost half below 30 cm).
soil_k_differences.NTS_vs_CSTCSM_K_content_0-20cm: NTS had more than twice the K available (0.53 vs 0.26 cmol c dm⁻³).
soil_k_differences.K_balance_offtake_rates: Ranged from 47% (CSTCM) to 70% (CSTCSC), with NTS at 52%.

comparative_analysis.statistical_significance: Means compared by Tukey test (p ≤ 0.05) for K content within each depth. Not statistically compared between sampling depths or for native Cerrado.

quality_control: Methodologies described in Teixeira et al. (2017).
Methodologies described in Teixeira et al. (2017).

sampling_design.spatial_sampling: Soil samples collected from experimental plots and an adjacent native Cerrado area. At each depth, 10 soil samples were collected and homogenized to form a composite sample for laboratory analysis.
sampling_design.temporal_sampling: Initial sampling in August 2005 (0-20 cm depth). Final sampling in October 2014 (0-5, 6-10, 11-20, 21-30, 31-60, and 61-100 cm layers).
sampling_design.sample_processing: Homogenization of 10 soil samples to form a composite sample.
sampling_design.representativeness: Composite samples aimed to represent the K status within each plot and depth layer.

uncertainty_sources: Assumption of soil bulk density equal to 1.0 kg dm⁻³ for K₂O equivalent calculations.
Exchangeable K contents were not statistically compared between sampling depths.
Native Cerrado K levels were not statistically compared with production systems.

climate_conditions.temperature: Not specified, but typical for Aw climate.
climate_conditions.precipitation: Average rainfall of 1,800 mm, concentrated from October to March.
climate_conditions.seasonality: Rainy season from Oct to Mar, off-season (autumn-winter) for cover crops.

soil_properties.classification: Clayey dystrophic Red Latosol (Santos et al., 2013), Typic Haplorthox (Oxisol) (Soil Survey Staff, 2014).
soil_properties.texture: Clayey (495 g kg⁻¹ clay, 217 g kg⁻¹ silt, 288 g kg⁻¹ sand at 0-20 cm depth initially). Fine texture.
soil_properties.mineralogy: Highly weathered soils with low-activity clays, low frequency of 2:1 clay minerals, predominance of variable charges.

organic_matter.trend: Naturally low OM content. Increased OM in NTS due to cover crops and residues. Strong relationship between SOM and exchangeable K.

chemical_properties.CEC: 6.33 cmol c dm⁻³ (0-20 cm initial); SOM accounts for most CEC in these soils.

physical_properties.bulk_density: Assumed 1.0 kg dm⁻³ for K₂O equivalent calculations.

landscape_context.topography: Altitude 557 m. Experiment installed in a field almost flat.
landscape_context.land_use_history: Three years of cotton cultivation prior to experiment, before that, soybean monoculture, with the soil prepared annually by plowing and harrowing.

research_integration.relationship_to_other_measurements: Soil K dynamics are strongly related to soil organic matter (SOM) content and cation exchange capacity (CEC). K export is directly linked to crop yields. K distribution in the profile is influenced by tillage and root activity.
research_integration.integration_with_plant_studies: The study integrates soil K with plant processes by evaluating K export by harvested products, K cycling by cover crops (ruzigrass), and the impact of K availability on cotton yield potential.
research_integration.connection_to_broader_objectives: The research contributes to improving K use efficiency in Brazilian agriculture and promoting sustainable cotton cultivation in highly weathered tropical soils, addressing issues of high K demand, leaching losses, and dependence on fertilizer imports.
research_integration.comparative_context: The study compares different soil management and crop rotation systems, including conventional tillage and no-tillage, and monoculture versus diversified cropping with cover crops, providing insights into their long-term effects on soil K.
research_integration.literature_positioning: The study builds upon existing knowledge of K dynamics in tropical soils, emphasizing the role of no-tillage and cover crops in K conservation and cycling, and referencing previous works on K supply, cycling, and use efficiency in similar environments.

measurement_constraints: Exchangeable K contents were not statistically compared between the sampling depths.
The reference soil from the native Cerrado area was not statistically compared with the production systems for exchangeable K levels.
temporal_limitations: Soil K dynamics were assessed at two time points (initial and after nine years), limiting detailed short-term temporal analysis.
spatial_limitations: While multiple depths were sampled, the study is confined to a single experimental site in the Cerrado biome.
methodological_constraints: The estimation of K₂O equivalent amounts stored in the soil profile assumed a constant soil bulk density of 1.0 kg dm⁻³ over the entire sampling profile, which might introduce some uncertainty.
interpretation_caveats: The study highlights the importance of K retention in the root zone but does not quantify the exact amount of K lost via runoff or leaching beyond the 100 cm depth.

extraction_assessment.extraction_notes: All explicit soil K related information, including quantitative measurements, methodological details, and contextual factors, has been extracted. Limitations and assumptions stated in the paper are noted. The native research context and terminology have been preserved. Enhancements focused on adding specific quantitative values from figures and enriching mechanistic descriptions based on textual cues.

enhancement_summary.enhancement_justification: Enhancements were made to provide more granular quantitative data, deepen the mechanistic understanding of soil K processes, and add specific details on management practices and environmental context, all directly sourced from the original paper, to improve the extraction's utility and accuracy.

validation_certification.validator_notes: The Stage 2A extraction was largely accurate. The validation process focused on enriching quantitative details, particularly from figures, and expanding on mechanistic descriptions of K processes and management practices as described in the text. No critical errors were found, and the enhancements significantly improve the completeness and depth of the soil K characterization.
